openstack/compute/v2/_proxy.py.message:
Noted it in another review, but it would be nice to set the arguments explicitly here. Can we do that? Looking at the source [1], 'name' is mandatory and 'availability_zone' is optional.

  def create_aggregate(self, name, availability_zone=None):

Don't forget the docstring :)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eb279e9a5676f4142cce4700c3097ecc14161895/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/aggregates.py#L26-L42

We do not actually want to have it globally this way, since any change on the server side (something else become mandatory) would require us to update all interfaces. Instead we simply pass what the user gives relying that he knows what to do. Another side is that depending on the server version something might be not mandatory on older releases and mandatory on newer, SDK must be backward/forward compatible.

I get where you're coming from, but I don't necessarily agree in this instance. This particular API has always accepted those parameters and if it changed in the future, we would eventually need to make changes to openstacksdk to support the new microversion but the '_max_microversion' would protect us until then, right?

Also, we already have a couple of occurrences of explicitly specifying all parameters in this file alone:

- create_server_image
- create_console
- create_flavor_extra_specs

Plus a few that specify the mandatory parameters at least:

- create_server_interface
- create_volume_attachment
- create_server_remote_console

We also do it for many of the non-create functions too

Hmm, I have not noticed those cases (not created by me). Generally we always were trying to have this only in exceptional cases, since the real life proves it is not a bloomy glowy as we might expect.
For the second part of your list some other stuff applied: we can not modify sub-resource without knowing the resource.

A yet additional "practice" is to leave proxy/resource layer a complete "low-level", while having then cloud layer doing lot's of desired validations and so on. So there I would not object in any way, but here I would really rather prefer leaving all params this way

We are currently not having a way to do that. I agree it might make sense, but definitely not in the scope of this change - this would be a huge change
These are also sort of read-only in that you have to use the actions to set them (idk why it was engineered that way but it was)

nit:

  return None

would achieve the same thing
ha, this is the same as "if a: raise() else: bar()"  ;-)

This isn't a valid request as used at [1]. The API appears to expect a list of objects (bad API design, I know). Either 'images' should be a list of objects and the docstring should indicate this, or it should be a list of IDs and we should transform this to objects with an 'id' key

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/762134/3/openstackclient/compute/v2/aggregate.py@413

I'm really not a fan of using sleeps in our tests. What I did for the similar races with resize/migration confirm/revert was to hook into some call between the changing of instance.host and the final save, and simply call the periodic task manually (i.e. change Ifea9a15fb01c0b25e9973024f4f61faecc56e1cd).

Perhaps you could wrap the 'drop_migration_context' call in this manner?

Unfortunately no. We need that the evac start first then periodic starts, but not finishes, then evac finishes, then periodic finishes. If I run the whole periodic at drop_migration_context then I could not reproduce the situation described at #4). In general it is not 

  evac
   |
   |
   |     periodic
   |        |
   |        |
   |        x
   |
   |
   x

but 

  evac
   |
   |
   |     periodic
   |        |
   |        |
   |        |
   x        |
            |
            x

what I need.

Starting the periodic from the test in a separate thread at drop_migration_context() might work but I don't think that we want that extra complexity in the test code either. Also it might need a sleep still to make the reproduction stable but only one sleep instead of two.
Done
Okay, fair. As an aside, that ^ would be a super comment to add to the code here

  self._evacuate_server(server, 'host2')
super nit: we usually add a FIXME note
Done

I'm thinking of we just depend on the sleep, it pretty depends on luck.

How about we use a flag to sync two threads.

We can set the flag as true here. But the 'slow_get_mig' will sleep until the flag set as true.

tl;dr: the flag based is too strict to work in both before and after the bug.

The flag based solution I could created only works until I fix the bug with an extra lock. After fixing the bug the test deadlocks as it still tries to enforce the same strict order of execution that leads to the error, but that is not possible any more with the extra locking. This defeats the goal of having a test case for reproduction that only differs in asserts between before and after the bug is fixed. 

I've pushed the lock based test separately[1]. So if you can figure out a flag based solution that reproduces the bug and also keeps the test intact after the bug fix is applied then let me know. 

[1] https://review.opendev.org/762872
sorry about that. I missed that after we fixed the bug, then it will become a deadlock. I guess this is the only way for now.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: This is a perfectly sensible solution. However, we already have things like 'abort_instance_claim' and 'drop_move_claim' in the resource tracker. Would, a new 'confirm_evacuate_claim' helper be reasonable? (wrapped in the '@utils.synchronized' decorator, naturally)
Thanks. If you do end up reworking these, feel free to stick me on the review. I'm all for it :)

That was basically my first solution in PS1[1]. But I did not like to move the logic out from here just to warp it with a lock. I think that solution trades the readability to solve a technicality. 

I know that this is now a different style that we had before. But honestly I also feel bad about our existing style:

    def function_without_lock():
        
        @utils.synchronized(lock-name)
        def function_with_lock():
            # logic or even another _do_function function call
        
        function_with_lock()


It would be a lot lest cruft to say:

    def function():
        with lock:
            # logic 

Sure the later needs an actual lock objects instead of lock-name hence the property returning the lock from the RT.

I'm OK to go back to PS1 style if the goal is to preserve style I just feel bad about it.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/#/c/754815/1/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py@1991

Personally, I prefer the PS1 style purely because that means everything's being done the same way and once I understand one path then I understand them all. With that said, I agree though that going with context managers rather than decorators could lead to much less of this inner function silliness. I guess it depends on whether we ever plan to copy this approach to the existing examples and remove e.g. the 'drop_move_claim_at_dest' and 'abort_instance_claim' helpers. If so, let's do this. If not, let's keeping the same pattern across similar code paths?

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: I hate to move this out from the compute manager rebuild flow but it seems that the COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE is owned by the resource tracker and there is no easy way to provide a context manager locking the semaphore as nova built infra around the synchronized decorator.
OK, I think I solved this.

It would be misleading. This function call itself does not lock the underlying semaphore. It just returns a context manager wrapping that semaphore.  The caller needs to activate the context manager by putting it in a `with` construct to have it locked.

swift/obj/expirer.py.message:
I found the 409 here means if the object changed (i.e. reuploaded, newer timestamp) after the async=on DELETE was issued it would just NOT get deleted (assuming all primaries were online and in-sync; I'm sure there's some failure mode that writes a tombstone somewhere and it IS deleted which questions the wisdom of returning 409 in the first place)

404 here is great, it means the client can also handle cleanup if the expirer is running late

If we write down a tombstone, it'll have the (high precision!) timestamp, so if there was an overwrite out on some handoff, we'd compare timestamps, last write would win, and we get all the normal eventually-consistent behavior we've come to expect.

Note that today, on master, there are no checks that we're actually deleting the same data that was referenced in the manifest. If you create a manifest and overwrite one of the segments with different data, when you issue a ?multipart-manifest=delete request it's gonna get deleted.

test/probe/test_object_expirer.py.message: I think this isn't great.  What's the listing look like?  What happens if the client overwrites these segments at this point?

As long as you've got low time skew between servers and some "reasonable" gap between the delete and the re-upload, it'll be fine. The deletes will still be scheduled, but for a timestamp that predates the new segment. So when the expirer comes around to it:

* object-server responds 409,
* expirer cleans up the queue, and 
* the segment data is still there, accessible and in listings.

That's part of why I got high-precision timestamps into the expirer queue -- I'd see 409s on the DELETEs and the segments would still show up in listings down at line 391. I debated about just adding one to the delete timestamp, but then I got to worrying about someone issuing an async delete then turning around and overwriting the segments -- and I didn't want the scheduled delete to be able to delete the new data.
this probe test is really great; kudos

zuul/connection/__init__.py.message: What is the purpose to rename this method? It looks to me like it's still clearing the branch cache.
This method is called for any connection (for example: SMTP, SQL). Even if Git based drivers implement it, a more generic name seems more adequate.

The name of this class is a bit misleading since the GerritConnection caches branches as well but doesn't use this class. In fact this class handles the concept of protected branches so it should be named accordingly. I'm just not sure about a good name. Maybe something like BaseConnectionBranchProtection or something shorter/better that is similar.

Not sure, but it might also be worth exploring the idea if it makes sense to make this class a mix in instead of a base class of those connections.

I plan to reuse this class with Gerrit and Pagure too (they don't support protected branches).

I used a mixin first, in the end I prefer to use a base class.

We're python3 only so this can be simpler:

  super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
This should be camel case to be consistent with the context.

I find it confusing having a getProjectBranches and a projectBranches method within the same class. It looks like getProjectBranches is meant as an external interface that leverages caching and projectBranches is used internally for fetching them.

What do you think about renaming this method to _fetchProjectBranches then? This makes the purpose and also the scope clear.
Should be camel case to match.

This comment should be in the docstring for this method, with a note indicating when implementing drivers should call it.  The base driver classes are the one place in Zuul where we try to keep a pretty high standard for docstrings for the benefit of driver authors.

I'd also prefer a more descriptive name for this method, perhaps "clearConnectionCacheOnBranchEvent" or something like that at least something to connect this to the connection cache so it's clear this isn't doing something like forwarding an event to the scheduler.
Each of the 3 previous methods should have docstrings.
To be consistent this method should have the type annotation too.

The reason for the change is that we should use "either" with a singular noun. We use "either of" with a plural noun. We could rewrite to "either of instances of" but I feel it's not as simple.

(native US English speaker)

I think both old and new are fine here, but the new one is a bit more clear.
Same comment here, both old and new were good enough, but the new is a small improvement.

The reason for the change is that the subject "A sample policy file" needs to "be maintained". It cannot maintain itself, so, we need a passive voice here. It's consistent with the "be generated" passive voice.

Is "operations" the name of one attribute of the class? If so, even though the word "operations" is plural, it represents one thing that is a container of other things, and I would say

  requires a new `operations` attribute that is a list of dictionaries.

"let's" is a contraction of "let us" and is less informal than I would expect to see in documentation and possibly harder for non-native speakers to interpret. Changing it to "we can" is still fairly informal, but clearer. Using "it is possible to" would be a bit more formal.

actully disk_available_least is not the actual disk usage on the hypervior.

it is the amount fo disk space that would be free on the hypervior if all the instance currently allocated to that hypervrios were to use all there disk  taking into account other factors like over commit and  and actual usage 

this is how its calulated

free_gb = total size of filesystem (minus) physical size on filesystem of all instance disks (minus) anything other than instace disks on that filesystem (e.g., /var/lib/nova/instance/_base/*)
overcommitted_total_gb = virtual size of all instance disks (i.e., how big their flavor specifies) (minus) physical size on filesystem of all instance disks
disk_available_least = free_gb - overcommitted_total_gb

https://gist.github.com/JCallicoat/43505cab0535057ca4fb

there are cases wehre disk_available_least can be negitve which corresponde to case where you have decreased the disk allocation ration to a point were the vm currently on the host would exceed the over commit raitio if they were to use all disk. it also can be negitive if you force migitrhation too a hos bypassing the scudler(pre placment service).

but yes tl;dr its hard to use and enduser dont understand what it actully is so we really shoudl not hav ethis.

it also does not take into account pageszie.
it shoudl really only be repoting 4k pages but it include hugepages as free is caluated by taking the total ram and subtracting the vms current useage based on flavor. it
does not correspond to the "free" commandline output which causes operators confusion.

The SNMP solution is not considering to cover the upgrade scenario from STX 4.0 (old StarlingX implementation) to STX 5.0 (new StarlingX implementation). The
rationale for this is that SNMP is not a system-critical service and the amount of SNMP configuration, that would need to be re-configured, is extremely small.

The resulting behaviour for software upgrade from STX 4.0 to STX 5.0 will be that any existing SNMP Configuration from the STX4.0 deployment will be lost.  After finishing the software upgrade to STX 5.0, the new SNMP Armada application will need to be installed and the old SNMP configuration re-entered as helm overrides for this new SNMP Armada application.

Software upgrades from STX 5.0 to future release will be supported with no configuration loss.

heat/cmd/manage.py.message: I wonder if this part would be better handled with a --dry-run flag to the existing command?

This is going to be inhumanly slow, because you have to iterate through every stack (including ones that have already migrated, or were created with convergence) every time, make an RPC call for each, load all the data from the DB.

We're already changing the RPC API anyway, and this could be implemented extremely efficiently on the engine side by doing all of the checking in the database. Why not just add a new method that does that?

Note that we will also need this for the upgrade checker if we want to eliminate the legacy code at any point.

A few thoughts:
* Should check that the list is not empty before printing this
* It would be better to print IDs as we encounter them, in case there's an error or something.
* We need a way at least of printing the IDs one-per-line with no text surrounding them, so that people can easily grab them from a bash script and use them to call migrate. I'd suggest always printing that to stdout and a message to stderr saying that there were or were not unmigrated stacks.
* Should we have a different return value if no stacks are found?
In the migrate command we called in convergence_1. Even though there's now not likely to ever be another, I feel like it would make sense to be consistent in the naming.

We cannot go with the RequestSpec way. The current code assumes a proper request spec where flavor (and other things) are filled. However during interface attach we don't want to allocate resources based on the flavor of the instance as that was already done during the boot. If we use a proper request spec then we request a double-up allocation of the instance that might not fit to the current host. 

What we need is allocation candidate that for the resource request of the port being attached, on the RP tree where the current allocation is. Then we need to extend the instance allocation with the selected candidate.

all of those steps need to be done synchronously by only one compute method. For the moment, we only synchronize on allocation updates and PCI claiming, but I personnally think we need to handle all of those actions by once and provide exceptions above them directly.

cinder/image/image_utils.py.message: Is it feasible to rename this to "image_info_cpu_limit"?

Thanks for the detailed explanation, Brian.

Let's wait for Eric's decision.

Yes, we can redefine the options like this:

    cfg.IntOpt('image_qemu_img_info_cpu_limit',
               deprecated_name='image_conversion_cpu_limit',
               deprecated_since='Wallaby',
               default=60,
               help='CPU time limit in seconds for "qemu-img info" calls'),
    cfg.IntOpt('image_qemu_img_info_address_space_limit',
               deprecated_name='image_conversion_address_space_limit',
               deprecated_since='Wallaby',
               default=1,
               help='Address space limit in GB for "qemu-img info" calls'),

oslo.config will look for the old names if the new ones aren't found, and if they are in the config file, it will log a message the first time they are accessed.  The generated config file will show this:

    # CPU time limit in seconds for "qemu-img info" calls (integer value)
    # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/image_conversion_cpu_limit
    #image_qemu_img_info_cpu_limit = 60

    # Address space limit in GB for "qemu-img info" calls (integer value)
    # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/image_conversion_address_space_limit
    #image_qemu_img_info_address_space_limit = 1

The deprecated_since doesn't really do anything, but is there for us to know when to remove the deprecated names (if we want to do that).  Of course, we will have to change to using the new names in our code (or else we will cause the deprecation message to be logged).

Another possibility is to add advanced=True to the option definitions.  Then what happens is the options are moved to the end of the "# from cinder" section and look like this:

    # CPU time limit in seconds for "qemu-img info" calls (integer value)
    # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/image_conversion_cpu_limit
    # Advanced Option: intended for advanced users and not used
    # by the majority of users, and might have a significant
    # effect on stability and/or performance.
    #image_qemu_img_info_cpu_limit = 60
    
    # Address space limit in GB for "qemu-img info" calls (integer value)
    # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/image_conversion_address_space_limit
    # Advanced Option: intended for advanced users and not used
    # by the majority of users, and might have a significant
    # effect on stability and/or performance.
    #image_qemu_img_info_address_space_limit = 1

Or we could keep the old names but make them "advanced" with the new help text.  I think Eric's aim here is to keep the options available so support can tell operators to change them, but we don't want people monkeying with them thinking that they do something other than what they do.  So I would be OK with changing the help text, marking them advanced, and keeping the names if that's what Eric thinks best.

cinder/policies/base.py.message:
why we didn't add the domain roles ? namely,
DOMAIN_ADMIN
DOMAIN_MEMBER
DOMAIN_READER

We certainly can if cinder is planning on supporting domain scope. I was hesitant to add them here in this patch because I wasn't sure if that would be in scope for wallaby.

Based on conversations we had in keystone, and with other projects, system and project user support is more pressing than domain support.

I'm happy to adjust this as necessary though if cinder has other plans. I just didn't want to add something that wasn't going to get used right away.

Thoughts?

Makes sense.
Since this change is harmless unless used in policies or exposed to user as a rule, i thought it was better to add all combinations but i agree that most of the policies will probably use system or project scope and we can add the domain policies later if needed.

There's one other thing you do that's not mentioned here, namely, before you make a create call to the backend, you first check to see if a volume with the requested name already exists--so even if the configured timeout is too small, you will prevent creation of a duplicate volume.  Might be worth mentioning somewhere (maybe a docs follow-up?) that if you see a bunch of 'Volume name [%s] already exists in SolidFire backend.' errors in the log, the sf_volume_create_timeout should be increased.

You are correct, I've added the initial checking to the list in commit message. I will also add a note in SolidFire docs regarding suggesting operators to increase sf_volume_create_timeout in case of frequent "Volume already exists" messages. Thanks for the suggestion!

tox.ini.message:
I find this comment bit confusing for multiple reasons:
a) you do not know which version zuul uses (is not defined here), also zuul may use multiple versions
b) old versions will not be able to highlight a serious range of issues and deprecations
c) linting is not functional testing, it does provide much ensurance that that code will run correctly on a particular version of ansible

If you really want to run a ansible-linting with the oldeds version of Ansible supported by current repository, you can try to create an additional job like a "tox-linters-lower" that does this.

Still, when running a single time, by far the vest results will be obtained from using latest versions. I would personally even advocate to run on 2.10.
